reasoning: The critique targets a subset of the essay’s illustrative empirical assumptions (e.g., digital beings as owned property; rapid, large-scale interstellar expansion). These examples support the ‘eutopia is fragile’ picture, but the core conclusion (‘no easy eutopia’) is defended via many other independent pathways (population ethics variability, value-function fussiness/linearity arguments, aggregation of bads, etc.), so falsifying these particular empirical assumptions would only modestly weaken the position (low centrality). The critique’s argumentative force is limited because it is generic (‘without sufficient engagement’) and doesn’t show that the essay’s conclusions materially depend on these premises, nor does it provide counterevidence; at most it nudges probability mass toward “uncertain” (low strength). Still, it is broadly correct that these premises are uncertain and contested, and the point is understandable though underspecified (moderate correctness/clarity). It stays focused on one issue and contains little filler (high single-issue, low dead weight).
title: Speculative empirical premises about digital beings and colonization lack sufficient justification
